Use me to write a one paragraph abstract and place it in index.Rmd as well as under the title of 01.Rmd. Once defined, you can reuse me simply by writing (ref:abs1) where you want this text to go. Abstract of my second cool idea I’m also an abstract! And a text reference! An abstract is all three acts of your story in a tight little package. 1 My first cool idea is a pricing model 1.1 The pricing solution proposed. 1.2 so what?.

1 My first cool idea is a pricing model 1.0.0.1 Keywords {SaaS, Pricing, B2B, Negotiations, Software Deals} 1.1 The pricing solution proposed. The practical solution for pricing better within a B2B software business is deploying a discount management model. In other words, to accelerate growth, B2B software firms can develop a pricing capability that enables users to understand favorable and unfavorable price ranges for each potential deal instantly or nearly so. A discount management model requires a few standard data elements to use in segmentation include customer, market, and product. We’re looking to understand and predict willingness-to-pay for customers of a given firm, so at minimum we need historical transaction data along with segmentation elements from that firm. To use a generic example familiar to all MIDS students as offer a quick segmentation illustration, UC Berkeley educates full-time students and part-time students (customer), caters to a local market and an international market (market), and offers undergraduate product, master product, and doctorate product (product). B2B busiensses typically retain these three types of data of a generally reliable quality in a CRM tool. These types of data and optionally others that that are both statistically and sensibly relevant for particular circumstances, will be blended to train a model aimed at predicting good discounts for any given deal within the scope of the model. Since our objective function is business optimization, as opposed to model optimization, deployability is a key requirement. A buzz-worthy neural network or random forest might optimize accuracy for a training or testing set, but a simpler tree, regression, or a combination might deliver tangible progress and also be feasibly productionalized. These simpler algorighms also tend to yield more human insight into relationships in the data (a.k.a. business insights) than do black box models. Once designed, the model will be deployed into the existing sales and deal negotiation process, and may be used by sales teams, sales management, deal desks, product groups, marketing among others. Implementation can take the form of a productized solution or a customization of existing software, eg Salesforce. In an environment where the next best alternatives are tribal knowledge and back of the napkin math, this solution guides pricing when and where it matters to alter sales behavior. Once deployed, many internal organizations benefit by gaining a deeper understanding of demand faced by the firm. 1.2 so what?. Pricing is important because it helps firms to maximize the utility its products generate by accessing and serving more customers, and to do a better job translating utility generated into revenue. Secondarily, this model helps convey a common standard of demand and product value across the firm, often forcing cross-functional communication about serving customers that otherwise might not occur. In other words, in addition to improving the top line in the short term, a well constructed pricing function forces a firm to be aligned and focused on creating customer value, which improves long term profitability. This function can be constructed around a discount management model. As research including the McKinsey study above indicate, the pricing lever is pressurized. Successfully deployed successful models can substantially acceperate growth, however, successfully deployed unsuccessful models achieve failure and can harm the business.
2 Universal Utility 2.1 Everyone has unique tastes 2.2 A know-it-all. 2.3 An end.

2 Universal Utility <<<<<<< HEAD #### Keywords {universal utility, utility} ======= >>>>>>> d0372646eb57d9f3409fedd0d8adf79b0c083b1c 2.1 Everyone has unique tastes We often think we know someone, either others or ourselves, but are later surprised by a decision or action. We think something like “that doesn’t seem like him/her to do that.” Since people rarely do things that are not useful to them in some way, actions might be deduced to priortized lists of options weighted by utility. An example to illustrate: Everyone has a unique set of tastes and preferences for what to eat. This set is at a granular level, for example it might include something like this: {“raw orange mini carrots”:12.5, “sliglty cooked orange mini carrots”:11.5,…“haricot verts sauteed in brown butter and sage”:16.8…}. We might posit that since each person has a set of tastes different than each other person, the notion of a restaurant would not seem possible to exist profitably. However, restaurants actually exist and make money. It seems that a limited number of offerings still satisfy a critical mass of unique tastes. When I order at a restaurant I look at the menu and pick the one that looks most satisfactory to me based on my Priorities (healthy, not healthy, contains alergy-inducing ingredients) and priorites (seared big eye tuna: 1 billion, canned albacore tuna: 2, steamed opakapaka: 200). Broadly speaking we all have a currnelty undefinable set of value drivers that 1) change over time and 2) seem to apply to everything. Try to think of a thing that exists, and then try to claim you have no sense of how useful it might be to you. (Let me know if you can!). 2.2 A know-it-all. The idea is to create a universal utility model that can estimate utility of anything. This requires tremendous amounts of data on every activity a person undertakes and a very large inference matrix. If I have eaten Pho at Pho Basil in Boston six times, and other people who ate at Pho Basil around six times also have never been on a ducktour (Boston tour bus-boat), the model might infer that I am unlikely to have a preference for, or get utilty from, a ducktour. If I have have a low preference for a ducktour, and other people who have a low prefernce for a ducktour also ski annually, I am likely to ski annually. To follow the example in class, this model will know that if I clicked 10 times on bananas and other people who clicked about 10 times on bananas also like apples, I probably like apples. 2.3 An end. Such a model will be useful to help align market offers to market preferences more precisely. Such added precision may improve utility return per dollar for consumers, and may help reduce waste overall as a greater society. If firms get better at offering higher utility offerings, then, all else equal, consumers will better off and society will waste fewer resources creating offerings that are less desireable. If, however, firms get better at offering higher utility offerings and also know how to price to utility, then firms will be better but consumers would not greatly beneift. As a tool, it could be used for good, for example, if open sourced and made available to everyone for free. It could also be used as a competitive advantage by firms if it is not offered as open source. The most likely scenario would evolve as an open source tool with premium customization, services and extensions built on top, with service providers akin to redhat.
